    • CSS vs jQuery

    This demo shows the differences between using CSS transitions and jQuery transitions. What's the difference? In a nutshell, CSS uses your graphic card to process the transition, where as using jQuery uses your main processor. However jQuery is generally more backwards compatible than CSS. That said, CSS transitions will revert to jQuery is the browser doesn't support CSS transitions.

    CSS

    jQuery

    HTML Markup

    <h3>CSS</h3>
<ul id="css-demo">
  <li title="This is caption 1 <a href='#link'>Even with links!</a>">

      <img src="/images/image-1.jpg" alt="demo1_1">
    </a>
  </li>
  <li title="This is caption 2">
    <a href="#slide2">
      <img src="/images/image-2.jpg"  alt="demo1_2">
    </a>
  </li>
  <li title="And this is some very long caption for slide 3. Yes, really long.">
    <a href="#slide3">
      <img src="/images/image-3.jpg" alt="demo1_3">
    </a>
  </li>
  <li title="And this is some very long caption for slide 4.">
    <a href="#slide4">
      <img src="/images/image-4.jpg" alt="demo1_4">
    </a>
  </li>
</ul>
<h3>jQuery</h3>
<ul id="jquery-demo">
  <li title="This is caption 1 <a href='#link'>Even with links!</a>">

    </a>
  </li>
  <li title="This is caption 2">

    jQuery

    jQuery('#css-demo').slippry({
  // options
  useCSS: true,
});

jQuery('#jquery-demo').slippry({
  // options
  useCSS: false,
});
